comments.body: Can you show the code where you are decompressing, replacing, and then compressing again? There may be room for improvement

Not coded yet, but the idea is: 1. create a byte[] with the uncompressed document (using gzipinputstream). 2. Replace the 8-digit byte by byte (avoiding any temporary copy). 3. compress this byte[] using gzipoutputstream.

answers.title: Replace content in a gzip file without decompressing it
answers.body:
No. You'd have to decompress it, at least to find where and how the ID is coded. Then you can either a) be really smart and figure out how to reassemble a stream with a different ID but the same number of bits, using the currently defined code tables, essentially solving a puzzle (assuming that it can be solved at all), or b) recompress the whole thing with the new ID.

If you are in control of the compression of your starting point, you could specially prepare the stream for this by switching to no compression right before the ID, flushing the block, a stored block, right after the ID, and then continuing with compression. You could note where in the output stream that is. Then you could later replace the ID, which appears in the stream as those bytes directly. You would also need to update the CRC, for which you can exclusive-or the original CRC with a "raw" CRC of the exclusive-or of the old uncompressed data and the new uncompressed data. That is just the exclusive-or of the old ID and the ID, with a bunch of zeros preceding and following that to fill out the data length. A "raw" CRC is one in which the CRC register is initialized with zeros and for which is there no final exclusive-or.

title: Replace content in a gzip file without decompressing it
body:
I'm receiving from a webservice xml files compressed in gzip format. The original size of the xmls is about 80Mb, and the compressed version is about 10Mb. These xml files are stored in our cache.

The xml root contains an attribute representing an 8-digit unique ID. So, when we serve a response from cache, we need to change this ID with another one received from another webservice before returning the xml to the end user.

The process should be:

  1. Decompress the cache xml.
  2. Replace the cached ID by one received from a webservice.
  3. Compress the file again and return it to the client.

Is it possible to perform this replacement without decompressing the whole document and compressing it again? Any kind of partial read and write?

comments.body: Look around on spring bug tracker and if you don't find an existing one, submit a new bug report.
Are you using the correct jdbc driver for the database version?

@JustinKSU This should have nothing to do with the driver or database version. Debugging shows that the connection is stored in the threadlocal by Spring and not cleared out when the transaction rollsback.

Are you using a connection pool for your database connections? Most implementations will automatically evict unused connections, create new ones as needed, and let you test the connection before passing back to a calling class.

@MichaelPeacock That's not the issue here. The issue is that a connection is kept in a threadlocal, and it can get stale if enough time passes. The pool isn't involved here (so it can't check whether the connection is valid).

Usually the pool will handle killing dead connections.  If you are not using a pool, Spring may assume you are going to take care of this task.  When I use Tomcat and an Oracle driver, I tell it what validation query to use to check to see if the connection is still alive before using it again.  if it's dead, it will create a new connection.
I have updated the sample code to show more clearly that it is the call method2 (1st call ) that fails to clean up the connection in threadLocal

As @JustinKSU mentions, if you choose not to use a database connection pool, then you need to explicitly manage the connections in your code. Database connections are like file handles in that they're tied to external resources that you need to explicitly maintain (open, close, test for existence, etc) if you're not relying on some other api or framework to maintain these for you.  Are you saying that you are explicitly maintaining your connections in your code, and you are still getting stale connections?
@MichaelPeacock It's spring that's keeping the connection in a threadlocal. The pool is not involved here (except for getting the initial connection).

@MichaelPeacock  Spring is managing the database connections. Not my code. After the first call to method2, there is a connection left in the threadLocal that Spring continues to use without going to the dataSource -- in subsequent use of jdbcTemplate in that thread. In the example I show that with a second call to method2.
I am able to work around the issue by either of these 2 ways (1) running method2 in a new thread (2) Avoid spring jdbcTemplate and using straight JDBC in method2
Did you submit a bug report?
@Kayaman I will open a JIRA and post the JIRA here

Spring will manage creating new connections, and closing them when there's an exception, but the responsibility for making sure the connections are good is deferred to the javax.sql.DataSource implementation you're using when you create your JdbcTemplate. If your DataSource implementation isn't capable of closing stale connections, or if it's not able to test the connections before it allows JdbcTemplate to use them, then you need a different data source implementation. We use one of the many connection pool data sources available, which allows our apps to run for months between restarts.

@MichaelPeacock Perhaps you are still not understanding the issue. The issue is that Spring is taking a connection out of the connection pool, never returning it to the pool and trying to use it after the database server has terminated the connection. One the pool has handed out a connection to Spring, it is out of the picture - until spring return the connection or asks for another one
Opened JIRA jira.spring.io/browse/SPR-15194

Sorry @daManja - From the earlier comments, I got the impression that you were not using a connection pool. In your example, you're simulating long running transactions that extends beyond your connection timeout within a single thread. If your connection dies of old age while your method is running, you may want to look at ways to optimize your SQL or find other ways to partition your tasks so this doesn't happen.

title: SpringFramework /JdbcTemplate: database connection not cleanedup from threadlocal on transaction rollback
body:
In production , we are seeing Spring Framework (Spring-jdbc 4.2.4) not cleaning up the database connection that it stores in a thread local.

Subsequent usages of the same thread leads to jdbcTemplate getting a potentially stale connection (one terminated my mysql server) from threadlocal instead of getting a new one from the connection pool. When this happens we get a Broken pipe or communication link failure on the connection.

WrappedException: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.CommunicationsException: Communications link failure
The last packet successfully received from the server was 80,416 milliseconds ago.  The last packet sent successfully to
 the server was 1 milliseconds ago.     [source:]

or

at com.mysql.jdbc.SQLError.createCommunicationsException(SQLError.java:1038)
at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.send(MysqlIO.java:3621)
at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.sendCommand(MysqlIO.java:2429)
at com.mysql.jdbc.MysqlIO.sqlQueryDirect(MysqlIO.java:2594)
at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.execSQL(ConnectionImpl.java:2541)
at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.execSQL(ConnectionImpl.java:2499)
at com.mysql.jdbc.StatementImpl.executeQuery(StatementImpl.java:1432)
at com.mysql.jdbc.ConnectionImpl.isReadOnly(ConnectionImpl.java:3617)
... 336 more
Caused by: java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe
at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite0(Native Method)
at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite(SocketOutputStream.java:109)
at java.net.SocketOutputStream.write(SocketOutputStream.java:153)

The problem can be easily reproduced on a single thread with the following code

On mysql server set connection timeout to say 60 sec

mysql > set global wait_timeout = 60

In java code

mainMethod() {

  try {

    method1() ;

   } catch(Exception e) {

    method2() // this is the real call
    sleep(80secs)
    method2() // this is there to a simulate another request on same thread

   }


}

@Transactional
method1() {

    jdbcTemplate.execute("select 1") ;
    throw new RuntimeException() ;


}


@Transactional
method2() {

    jdbcTemplate.execute("select 1") ;

}

The 2nd call to method2 is there to simulate another request on the same thread after the first call method2 has leaked a db connection to the threadLocal

In debugging the code I observed that jdbcTemplate calls DataSourceUtils.getConnection to get a connection.

DataSourceUtils.getConnection first tries to get a connection from a ThreadLocal. It goes to the dataSource only if there is no connection in the threadLocal. In this scenario, it finds a terminated (due to timeout) connection in the threadLocal which causes Method2 to fail with a jdbc Broken pipe socket exception.

Changing method2 to @Transactional(propagation = Requires_NEW) did not help.

Is this a SpringFramework bug or should I be doing something differently ? How should the method2 ( the first call to method2) be done so it cleans up its db connection on the threadLocal

I've used a couple of print statements to check whats going on, and any print in the second part does not get printed. I also put everything in a while loop, which makes it stuck in the first loop-part of the above code.

Use a debugger, don't rely on print statements. Step filters will allow you to trace every single line of execution, showing you how you code is being executed. By using a debugger, you'll be able to determine where the problem is. IDEs usually come bundled with debuggers, such as Eclipse or IDEA
What's the value of dimension?  The best reason I can think of for skipping the second for loop is that dimension-1 is already 3.
if dimension is not 4, the second for loop (and all loops under it) will surely not executed.

@Warhost your modified for loop has a problem. if dimension is great than 4, the loop won't be executed, otherwise the loop might run forever (or for a long time till k cycles back to the maximum positive value) if there's no true condition of the if test ever met.

answers.title: Method stuck in for Loop with If Conditional
answers.body: I suspect that the i == 3 and k == 3 in your loop conditions are at least contributing to your problem. With these conditions the loops will get skipped unless dimension == 4.

comments.body: Thanks a lot, the problem is indeed the k == 3, I mistaken that for "until k is 3".

answers.title: Method stuck in for Loop with If Conditional
answers.body:
The condition part of your loops should be the problem here - 

for (int i = 0; i <= dimension-4; i++) {
    for (int j = 0; j <= dimension-4; j++) {
        for (int k = dimension-1; k == 3; k--)

the innermost loop executes only if dimension == 4 and since there is no modification within the loops to this variable.

The outermost and second loop doesn't even iterate more than once (the block would execute only once) if you do a j++ or i++ and at the same time check if i/j <= dimension(4)-4 resolving as i/j <= 0.

So certainly the loops need better handling with dimension specified and the conditions modified accordingly.

title: Method stuck in for Loop with If Conditional
body:
I am trying to check several entries in a game board by iterating over them in a specific order. Now what I noticed is that when the method is called by my junit test, it is stuck in the first for loop and doesn't continue with the next ones, and just returns false, meaning it jumps to the end of the method. When I run a test which just needs the first 3 loops, then it works, but another test requires the second loop, which doesn't get executed.

Question: Why is it jumping to the end without first checking the other loops?

    public boolean hasDiagonal(Mark m) {

    for (int i = 0; i <= dimension-4; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j <= dimension-4; j++) {
            for (int k = dimension-1; k == 3; k--) {
                if (getField(i  , j  , k  ) == m &&
                    getField(i+1, j+1, k-1) == m &&
                    getField(i+2, j+2, k-2) == m &&
                    getField(i+3, j+3, k-3) == m) {
                        return true;
                    //Stops here, if this part doesn't yield true,
                    //it returns false immediately
                }
            }
        }
    }

    //This doesn't get checked
    for (int i = dimension-1; i == 3; i--) {
        for (int j = 0; j <= dimension-4; j++) {
            for (int k = dimension-1; k <= 3; k--) {
                if (getField(i  , j  , k  ) == m &&
                    getField(i-1, j+1, k-1) == m &&
                    getField(i-2, j+2, k-2) == m &&
                    getField(i-3, j+3, k-3) == m) {
                        return true;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    return false;
}
